title: How to Prepare Walls for Wallpaper

steps.headline: Flip the breaker to shut off power to the room.
steps.description: You'll need to remove the light switches and outlet covers as well as clean the walls before you add wallpaper, so it's important to turn off the power to the room to prevent damage to your electrical circuits or electrocution. Find your breaker box and look for the diagram on the panel that labels the room or area that you want to shut off. Then, flip the breaker that controls the power to that room or area. Your breaker box may be located on the outside of the building. Use spotlights or plug a lamp into an extension cord that’s plugged into a nearby room so you can see while you’re working. If you can’t identify which breaker will shut off the power to the area you’re preparing to wallpaper, try testing it out by flipping several breakers until the power is turned off.

steps.headline: Move any furniture away from the walls.
steps.description: Furniture can impede your ability to access and move around the area near the walls to clean them and apply a primer base. Take any chairs, sofas, tables, or any other furniture out of the room or push them to the middle so they’re out of the way. Keep out any pets or small children while you’re working as well.

steps.headline: Unplug any electrical devices from the walls.
steps.description: Unplug any lamps, TVs, clocks, or any other devices that are connected to a wall outlet in the room. Take them out of the room so they’re not in the way while you’re working. Wrap their cords around them so they’re not a tripping hazard.

steps.headline: Remove any fixtures and hanging items from the walls.
steps.description: Remove any paintings, clocks, or decor that are hanging on the walls so you can prepare them for the new wallpaper. Use a screwdriver to unscrew light switches, electrical outlet covers, and any grates or vents that are on the walls so you can attach new wallpaper more easily. Take off light fixtures and anything else attached to the wall and set them aside. Place hanging decor in another room with any furniture that you moved away from the walls so they won’t get damaged while you work.Tip: Place all of the screws, nails, and other pieces in a plastic bag next to the fixture so you don’t lose any of them.

steps.headline: Lay drop cloths on the floor to protect it.
steps.description: Place drop cloths or a tarp on the floor to keep moisture, adhesive, and dirt and debris from getting onto it. Use painter’s tape to seal the cloths to the baseboards or edge of the wall so the floor is completely covered. You can also use plastic sheeting or even newspapers to cover the floor. Drop cloths, tarps, and plastic sheeting can be found at hardware stores, department stores, and online.

steps.headline: Cover the baseboards with towels.
steps.description: Cleaning the walls and applying wallpaper can cause water and adhesive to run down the walls. To keep your baseboards protected against possible water damage, lay down some towels over them as an added measure. Even with a drop cloth or plastic sheet, your baseboards could potentially be exposed because they’re flush against the wall.

steps.headline: Remove the old wallpaper and glue if there is any.
steps.description: If the wall already has wallpaper, remove it along with its adhesive backing. To remove the existing wallpaper, find a corner or edge of the wallpaper and start peeling it away from the wall. Pull off as much of it as you can with your hands, then use a putty knife to scrape off any stubborn bits of wallpaper and glue from the surface of the wall. Hold the putty knife at a 45-degree angle and keep the edge of it flat against the wall so you don’t damage the wall. If you don’t have a putty knife, use a metal spatula with a flat edge.Tip: If you’re having trouble removing sections of wallpaper, spray warm water on the area to saturate and soften it, then use a putty knife to scrape it off.

steps.headline: Scrape off loose paint with a putty knife.
steps.description: Before you add a primer coat to the wall, make sure there isn’t any paint that will affect the coat and the adhesion of the wallpaper. Use a putty knife to scrape off any loose chips or flecks of paint so there aren’t any bumps or pieces sticking up. You don’t need to remove all of the paint from the wall, but the surface needs to be smooth so the wallpaper won’t have any bubbles or bulges.

steps.headline: Sand the walls smooth with a power sander.
steps.description: The surface of the walls need to be smooth and consistent in order to prime them and hang wallpaper. Use a power sander with 120-grit sandpaper to sand the walls using a circular motion so the surface is smooth and the new wallpaper will adhere to it. If you have a textured wall, spend more time sanding it down. If you don’t have a power sander, you can rent one for the day from a local home improvement store.

steps.headline: Scrub the walls with warm water and vinegar to clean them.
steps.description: Clean the walls by combining 3 tablespoons (44 mL) of white vinegar with 1 gallon (3.8 L) of warm water in a bucket and submerging a sponge or clean cloth in the solution. Wring out the excess water so it isn’t dripping wet and use consistent, circular motions to scrub the walls and remove any dirt, grime, or lingering adhesive from the surface of the wall. Let the wall dry overnight when you’re finished. Wait at least 12 hours to allow the wall to fully dry. Use a sponge with a scrubbing surface to remove stubborn grime or glue from the wall. Warm water will help clean the wall better than cold water will.

steps.headline: Make sure that the wall is completely dry before you do anything else.
steps.description: Touch the wall with your hands to feel for any moisture on its surface. If it feels even slightly damp, wait another hour and then check it again. The walls need to be fully dry before you prime and apply wallpaper to it. Place fans in the room to circulate the air and help the walls dry faster.

steps.headline: Patch any gouges or damage to the wall by applying joint compound.
steps.description: Fix any holes, scratches, or gouges in your wall before you hang wallpaper on it so the surface is smooth and the paper isn’t uneven. Use a putty knife to spread a layer of joint compound over the damaged area and then allow it to dry overnight. You can find joint compound at home improvement stores, department stores, and online.Tip: If the hole or gouge is very small, use spackling paste instead of joint compound.

steps.headline: Fill the reservoir of a paint tray with an acrylic primer.
steps.description: A coat of standard white primer will create a uniform surface for your new wallpaper to stick to. Slowly pour the primer into the reservoir of a paint tray, but don’t overfill it so you can use the textured surface of the tray to remove excess primer. 1 gallon (3.8 L) of acrylic primer should be enough to cover the walls. You can find primer at home improvement stores, paint supply stores, and online.

steps.headline: Use a paint roller to apply a thin coat of primer to the walls.
steps.description: Dip a clean paint roller into the primer in the reservoir of the tray. Run the roller over the textured surface of the tray to remove the excess. Then, apply a thin, even coat to the wall, from the floor to the ceiling. Use smooth, even strokes to apply the primer. Apply more primer to the roller when it starts to run out.

steps.headline: Allow the walls to dry overnight.
steps.description: The primer needs to be completely dry before you apply any wallpaper glue and wallpaper to the walls or it could affect how well it adheres. Let the walls sit undisturbed overnight or wait at least 8 hours to let them dry. Test the primer to make sure it’s dry by touching it with your fingers. Point fans at the walls to help the primer dry faster.
